output_notebook()

x = m_country.Country.tolist() #Country as x-axis

source = ColumnDataSource(data=m_country) # connecting it to the table used above.

#Creating the plot
p = figure(plot_width=1000, plot_height=400, x_range=x)

#Adding the circles to the plot
p.circle("Country","Ratings",
         source=source, 
         size = 20, color="red")

#Adding labels

p.title.text = 'Average ramen ratings by country'
p.xaxis.axis_label = 'Country'
p.yaxis.axis_label = 'Average rating out of 5'
p.xaxis.visible = False #The countries were overlapping too much

hover = HoverTool()
hover.tooltips=[
    ("Country","@Country"),("Rating out of 5", "@Ratings")
]
p.add_tools(hover)

#Showing the graph
show(p)

# **The purpose of this mini-mini-project**

To turn my data viz work that I did previously in to an interactive graph because those are far more interesting than just plain graphs. 

I'll start off with practising with some of the graphs that I've already created and seeing what can be done from there. Below are the tutorials that I'm using because I'm still bad at coding: 

* [Visualising Data with Bokeh and Pandas](https://programminghistorian.org/en/lessons/visualizing-with-bokeh)
* [A Complete Guide to an Interactive Geographical Map using Python](https://towardsdatascience.com/a-complete-guide-to-an-interactive-geographical-map-using-python-f4c5197e23e0)
* [Bookeh Documentation (which is great!)](https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/quickstart.html)

I'll leave in some of my mistakes so that beginners like me can understand where my frustrations are so that they know they're not alone in finding this difficult!

To explain a lot of the mess that was above -- I was trying to make the countries the x axis but it simply never worked. All of the tutorials I looked at seemed to make sense until I put it into practice... 

... They worked on the assumption that both axes would be numerical data. I was using "categorical data" (names of countries). So I never received an error message, nor did I recieve anything useful. 

In order to handle categorical data, I'd need to use "x_range" in the figure() object in order for it to be registered. I think NOW I can add interactivity. 

No one told me no error message can be worse than an error message. **NO ONE.**

I'll add the interactivity as a different cell so that it isn't so confusing.
